fact_list.fact_text: Before moving off, fasten your seat belt and look in the mirrors.
Give the proper signal, look around to check on traffic and pedestrians.
Move off only when it is safe and does not cause inconvenience to other road users.
Give way to passing and overtaking vehicles.
Mirrors should be checked before moving off, slowing down, stopping, changing lane, overtaking, and making any turn.
Cultivate the habit of checking the mirrors every 5 to 10 seconds while driving.
Areas on the right and left of the vehicle which cannot be viewed in mirrors are known as 'blind spots'.
Turn your head and look over your shoulder to check for traffic in 'blind spots' before changing lane, overtaking, turning, or stopping.
Always give clear signals at least 3 seconds in advance of your intentions before any manoeuvre.
Constantly adjust your speed to the road conditions to stop in emergencies without skidding or losing control.
A good driver reduces speed when entering a built-up area.
A good driver reduces speed when approaching a school or a stationary bus with children alighting or boarding.
A good driver reduces speed when travelling on narrow winding roads.
A good driver reduces speed when approaching children playing.
A good driver reduces speed when approaching a bend, brow of a hill, or other obstructions that limit view.
A good driver reduces speed when the road surface is wet.
Tailgating or following too closely behind another vehicle is a dangerous practice.
If the vehicle in front stops suddenly, an accident becomes inevitable since you won't be able to stop in time.
Tailgating makes the driver in front nervous and can cause involvement in an accident.
To maintain safe following distance, allow at least one car length for every 16km/h of your speed.
